parse.title: There was an old priest naméd Francis

links.*: A Closed Letter to Andrea Charicoryides Surnamed Polygrapheus, Logothete of the Theme of Geodesia in the Empire, Bard of the Court of Camelot, Malleus Malitiarium, Inclinga Sum Sometimes Known as Charles Williams
A Fragment of an Epic: Before Jerusalem Richard Makes an End of Speech
Adventures in Unnatural History and Medieval Metres, being the Freaks of Fisiologus
Bilbo's Last Song (at the Grey Havens)
Chip the glasses and crack the plates!
Cold be hand and heart and bone,
Dark Are the Clouds about the North
Far over the misty mountains cold
Farewell We Call to Hearth and Hall!
From dark Dunharrow in the dim morning
Hey dol! merry dol! ring a dong dillo!
Hop along, my little friends, up the Withywindle!
I Sit beside the Fire and Think
In Western Lands beneath the Sun
Lemminkainen Goeth to the Fords of Oxen
Over Old Hills and Far Away
Over the land there lies a long shadow
Poems in The Lord of the Rings
Seek for the Sword that was broken
Sir Gawain and the Green Knight
Song of the Ent and Entwife
Song of the Mounds of Mundburg
Tha Eadigan Saelidan: The Happy Mariners
The Battle of the Eastern Field
The Collected Poems of J.R.R. Tolkien
The Complaint of Mîm the Dwarf
The Homecoming of Beorhtnoth Beorhthelm's Son
The Invented Worlds of J.R.R. Tolkien
The J.R.R. Tolkien Companion and Guide
The Last of the Old Gods
The Lay of Aotrou and Itroun
The Lay of the Children of Húrin
The Lay of the Fall of Gondolin
The Lion Is Loud and Proud
The Little House of Lost Play: Mar Vanwa Tyaliéva
The Man in the Moon Came Down Too Soon
The Man in the Moon Stayed Up Too Late
The Swallow, and the Traveller on the Plains
The wind was on the withered heath
The world was young, the mountains green,
Twenty years have flowed away down the long river
Under the mountain dark and tall
When winter first begins to bite
Where now the horse and the rider? Where is the horn that was blowing?
The Mermaid's Flute from 'The Lay of Earendel'
The Horns of the Host of Doriath
An Ode Inspired by Intimations of the Approach of Early Morning Tea
Ye laggard woodlands and ye slumbrous brakes
I stood upon an empty shore before the sun was born
A Rhyme Royal upon Easter Morning
Moonshine: Verses in a Medieval Measure
Lines Composed in a Village Inn on an Evening of Extraordinary Liquid Beauty
The Tale of Beewolf Son of Echgethew
Völsungakviða en nýja eða Sigurðarkviða en mesta
Guðrúnarkviða en nýja eða Dráp Niflunga
Hit was an olde mon fro Pimbilmere
When little Louis came to stay
Though all things fail & come to naught,
My heart is not in this land where I live:
'At last the time has come,' he said,

wikitext.*:
{{Unnamed}} {{poem infobox | title="There was an old priest naméd Francis" | image= | caption= | imageWidth= | imageHeight= | other names= | written=[[8 August]] of [[1904]] | revised= | published=''[[Beyond Bree]]'', October 2020,
''[[Beyond Bree]]'', November 2020,
''[[The Collected Poems of J.R.R. Tolkien]]'' | subject=[[Francis Xavier Morgan]] }} "'''There was an old priest naméd Francis'''"{{CP|A1}}, "Limericks", pp. 1365-6 is the first line of a limerick written by [[J.R.R. Tolkien]] as part of [[Letter to Father Francis Morgan|a letter]] to [[Francis Xavier Morgan]] on [[8 August]] of [[1904]]."The AB Language Lives" by [[Arne Zettersten]] in ''[[The Invented Worlds of J.R.R. Tolkien|The Invented Worlds of J.R.R. Tolkien: Drawings and Original Manuscripts from the Marquette University Collection]]'' (2004) ==Poem== :There was an old priest naméd Francis :Who was so fond of 'cheefongy dances' ::That he sat up too late ::And worried his pate :Arranging these Frenchified Prances. ==Background== On [[8 August]], [[1904]], [[J.R.R. Tolkien]] wrote a limerick about [[Francis Xavier Morgan]] at the end of "a three-page pictorial code letter"{{CG|C}}, p. 10 (entry "8 August 1904") sent to the priest. The limerick, along with the letter, is kept "in the Tolkien Collection"{{webcite|author=[https://nonsenselit.com/author/margraz/ Marco Graziosi]|articleurl=https://nonsenselit.com/2014/06/17/tolkiens-nevbosh-limerick/|articlename=Tolkien’s Nevbosh Limerick|dated=17 June 2014|website=[https://nonsenselit.com/ A Blog of Bosh - Edward Lear and Nonsense Literature]|accessed=31 December 2025}} at the [[Bodleian Library]] in [[Oxford]]. The limerick, along with the letter, was published for the first time in the ''[[Beyond Bree]]'' issue for [[October]] [[2020]], together with a commentary by Denis Bridoux.{{webcite|author=[https://www.tolkienguide.com/profile/1 Jeremy Edmonds]|articleurl=http://www.tolkienguide.com/modules/newbb/viewtopic.php?post_id=27591|articlename=Tolkien's 1904 Rebus letter to Father Morgan|dated=14 October 2020|website=Guide|accessed=29 October 2020}} In their commentary, Bridoux suggested "that ''cheefongy'' may be a reference to ''chiffon'', a light, diaphanous fabric, and that the word 'Frenchified' may be an early example of the aversion to things French Tolkien expressed much later in life"."Letting Images Speak for Themselves: Tolkien's [[Letter to Father Francis Morgan|Rebus Letter to Fr. Francis Morgan]], August 8, 1904" by Denis Bridoux in ''[[Beyond Bree]]'', October 2020, pp. 1–2 Bridoux's speculation about the term ''cheefongy'' was confirmed by [[Mark Hooker]] as "a dialect word for 'chiffon'" in the ''[[Beyond Bree]]'' issue for [[November]] the same year."Annotated Transcription of Tolkien's 1904 [[Letter to Father Francis Morgan|Rebus Letter to Fr. Francis]]" by [[Mark Hooker]] in ''[[Beyond Bree]]'', November 2020, pp. 2–5 Hooker also "pointed out that in the first part of 1904 the expatriate avant-garde dancer Loïe Fuller was captivating audiences, including one in Birmingham where Tolkien lived, with her renowned 'Radiance Dance'", which could be related to "cheefongy dances" and "Frenchified Prances". In [[September]] of [[2024]], the poem was reprinted in Appendix I in ''[[The Collected Poems of J.R.R. Tolkien]]'', where [[Wayne G. Hammond]] and [[Christina Scull]] suggest in their commentary that Tolkien's "aversion to things French" may have been exaggerated. {{References}} {{Poems}} [[Category:Limericks and clerihews]]
